overview.name: Programme overview
overview.paragraph:
The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating economic impact, threatening the jobs and livelihoods of many South Africans – especially the most vulnerable. The pandemic has exacerbated South Africa’s pre-existing crises of poverty and unemployment. The Presidential Employment Stimulus recognises the urgency of this situation, using direct public investment to support public employment, job retention and livelihood support programmes, as part of the wider economic recovery process.  This provides direct support to participants and their families, but also acts as a stimulus in local economies, with spending mainly in township and rural economies. This provides a vital stimulus to small enterprise and the informal sector - trickling up into the wider economy from there.
This platform tracks the performance of the programmes that form part of the Presidential Employment Stimulus. It reflects work in progress, with the data updated monthly.
overview.footer_paragraph: The Presidential Employment Stimulus data is subject to ongoing verification and audit. The numbers reported may change based on final verification and audit outcomes.

departments.name: Agriculture, Land Reform and Rural Development
departments.lead: Expanding support to farmers and protecting food value chains
departments.paragraph: The pandemic has illustrated the vulnerability of our food production and distribution systems. Although exempt from the strictest lockdown regulations, the sector faced severe challenges with disruptions to production and marketing experienced by many small-scale farmers. The Presidential Employment Stimulus is supporting subsistence farmers, through the provision of production input vouchers. Applications were done on a USSD platform, providing DALRRD with a geo-spatially referenced data-base of subsistence farmers for the first time. Agricultural graduates are being used to do on-site verification of applicants, collecting additional data that provides a basis for future support also.

implementation_details.detail: The department continues to verify the 131 000 pre-approved applicants to ensure that farmer activity is as reported. The process of issuing vouchers to approved and verified applicants is underway. The department is also addressing challenges with certain suppliers that are charging more than the pre-agreed prices for inputs, taking a cut of the vouchers or disbursing cash instead of inputs for production. Although this is a small percentage of the total, DALRRD is following up on complaints and a number of suppliers have been blacklisted.

departments.name: Basic Education
departments.lead: School assistants strengthen the learning environment at schools
departments.paragraph: The Basic Education Employment Intervention (BEEI) of the DBE creates opportunities for a target of 300,000 young people, placed as school assistants at over 22,000 schools. This enables a high level of spatial equity, reaching communities everywhere. School assistants are selected by schools at the local level. There are two categories of assistants. For Education Assistant posts, matric is a requirement and graduates are prioritised. The Education Assistants support teachers in the classroom and assist with administration. For General Assistants, there is no minimum education qualification required. The General Assistants support maintenance and security at schools, as well as other tasks identified by the school. In addition, the stimulus supports teachers posts normally funded by School Governing Bodies at fee-paying schools, in a context in which parents were struggling to pay fees as a result of the economic impact of the pandemic. This placed these jobs at risk.

implementation_detail.detail: The department has placed close to 200 000 education assistants in schools across the country. These young people provide crucial support to teachers in the classroom and perform administrative tasks. Although due to conclude at the end of March, the value added by the assistants prompted all nine provincial departments to extend the education assistants contracts for another month to align with the end of the school term in April. The department is using the time to compile a comprehensive review of the programme and draw key lessons for future iterations.

The department has placed more than the anticipated 100 000 general assistants in all schools across the country. The general assistants are supporting maintenance and security at schools and other basic needs. Similar to the education assistants, provincial departments too a decision to extend contracts until end of April.

This programme is protecting vulnerable teacher posts across the schooling system. Although initially targeted at quintile 4 and 5 schools, the support was targeted to all other schools in recognition of support required in poorer schools as well. This funding support has been undersubscribed and so where possible, provinces have transferred the funds to support the extension of school assistants by another month.

departments.name: Co-operative governance
departments.lead: Mainstreaming and improving labour-intensity in infrastructure delivery
departments.paragraph: In certain areas of infrastructure delivery, labour-intensive methods can enhance the job creation impact, while delivering the same quality of infrastructure outcomes. While there has long been policy support for labour-intensive methods, these are not always used in practice. Through the stimulus, the Municipal Infrastructure Support Agency (MISA) of DCOGTA is building the capacity of municipalities to utilise these methods. Fifteen municipalities have been targeted; others have asked to join the process. This component is only expected to deliver results against the employment target in the 2021/22 financial year, because of the contracting cycle for municipal infrastructure.

implementation_detail.detail: The Municipal Infrastructure Support Agency (MISA)'s  appointed a service provider has begun work to deliver the capacity development in 15 municipalities. This includes improvements to reporting within EPWP and assisting in project design for the next financial year to incorporate labour intensive methods in infrastructure delivery.

departments.name: Environment, Forestry and Fisheries
departments.lead: Investing in the environment we live in
departments.paragraph: The work undertaken in environmental, forestry and fishery programmes will touch the length and breadth of the country, from coast to coast, including bushveld, grassland, fynbos, wetlands, mountains, water bodies, catchment areas  – and urban areas, too. The work undertaken affects the air we breathe, the water we drink, the energy we use and the food we eat, supporting a wealth of biodiversity resources and ecological systems essential to life on earth and to the future of the planet.

metrics.name: Cleaning and greening - war on waste with municipalities

implementation_detail.programme_name: Cleaning and greening - war on waste with municipalities
implementation_detail.detail: The programme plans cleaning activities and indigenous tree planting. After procurement delays, appointment of service providers is underway, with recruitment processes in place in all municipalities.

metrics.name: Department of Fisheries: War on Waste at Harbours and landing sites

implementation_detail.programme_name: Department of Fisheries: War on Waste at Harbours and landing sites
implementation_detail.detail: Project not started.

metrics.name: Oceans and Coast: Source to Sea

implementation_detail.programme_name: Oceans and Coast: Source to Sea
implementation_detail.detail: In 16 districts in the country, river embankments and waterways will be cleaned to prevent litter entering the ocean.

metrics.name: Groen Sebenzas, weather service - graduate programme

implementation_detail.programme_name: Groen Sebenzas, weather service - graduate programme
implementation_detail.detail: Graduate interns are being mentored in natural resource project management and some are doing fieldwork towards further qualifications in restoration ecology.
The infrastructure in 11 national botanical gardens and 2 zoological gardens is being maintained.
7 facilities in iSimangaliso have been maintained and upgraded, 36 kms of fencing has been maintained, with roads maintenance undertaken also.

Solar water heaters have been installed in Addo, Augrabies and Golden Gate, with solar plants in Tankwa in process. 33 SMEs have been supported to undertake the work, which includes 100 small renovations.

metrics.name: Catchment management and strategic water sources

implementation_detail.programme_name: Catchment management and strategic water sources
implementation_detail.detail: The programme is focused on the rehabilitation of catchment areas and strategic water resources in protected areas. This involves clearing alien invasive species (which reduce water availability and biodiversity) and limiting bush encroachment (which can reduce grazing capacity by up to 80%). The PES enabled clearing of alien invasive species from 29,414 hectares with follow up cleaning on 141 123 hectares.
Support to 19 traditional authorities on biodiversity, conservation and land rehabilitation is envisaged but has faced implementation challenges.

This programme is focussed on improving the sustainability of  plantations and indigenous forests and the development of forestry enterprises and also on support to disaster risk reduction in relation to veld and forest fires.

departments.name: Public Works and Infrastructure
departments.lead: Graduate placements in the professional services
departments.paragraph: In addition to structural skills shortages that were experienced prior to the pandemic, the management of facilities and completion of infrastructure projects has been further impacted by restrictions on the movement of people and limitations placed on completing infrastructure projects during the lockdown. As the economy re-opens, additional capacity is required to address the backlog so that service provision can be restored. The Presidential Employment Stimulus is supporting graduate placements in a range of programmes linked to facilities management and infrastructure delivery mandate of the department.  An additional benefit is that students on the programme will obtain sufficient work experience to obtain their qualification thus helping to reduce the backlog that the TVET Colleges and University of Technologies are experiencing.

departments.name: Sports, Arts and Culture
departments.lead: Getting artists, cultural workers and the sporting sector on the road to recovery
departments.paragraph: Under lockdown, there has been no loud applause in jazz venues, no curtain calls for the dancers, no tourists in craft markets – and no victory laps for our sports people. No segment of the creative, cultural and sporting sectors has been untouched. The stimulus is supporting a range of public employment programmes and job retention programmes for the creative and sports sectors. It has also supported a stimulus to support the creative sector to return to work, through grants to the National Arts Council and the National Film and Video Foundation.

implementation_detail.detail: The lockdown restrictions and the fact that most facilities have been closed has led to low demand from National Federations and thus the set target will not be reached. The programme concluded at the end of March with 613 jobs created in the sector.

metrics.name: Banking with art, connecting Lives - National Museum Bloemfontein

implementation_detail.programme_name: Banking with art, connecting Lives - National Museum Bloemfontein
implementation_detail.detail: The programme is concluding at the end of March and was able to meet its targets. The approved visual artists created artworks for consideration by the Art Bank of South Africa as part of economic recovery.

metrics.name: Assistance with business growth strategies and marketing plans - South African Cultural Observatory

implementation_detail.programme_name: Assistance with business growth strategies and marketing plans - South African Cultural Observatory
implementation_detail.detail: Following delays in obtaining approval, the National Treasury has granted the department permission to use South African Cultural Observatory (SACO) as an implementing agent for the programme. The department has issued a call to provinces to identify artists to be trained by appointed graduates. Although delayed, implementation is now in process.

metrics.name: Public Art, towards a people's culture - Community Arts Centres

implementation_detail.programme_name: Public Art, towards a people's culture - Community Arts Centres
implementation_detail.detail: Several provinces have begun implementation following significant delays in signing the Memorandum of Agreement with implementing agents. The programme is implementing strategies to fast track implementation to meet outstanding milestones  before conclusion in March.

metrics.name: Audit of national museums - South African Heritage Resources Agency

implementation_detail.programme_name: Audit of national museums - South African Heritage Resources Agency
implementation_detail.detail: The programme appointed young people to conduct audits of memorials, monuments and statues around the country. It is progressing well and approximately 1600 memorials, monuments and statues have been recorded across the country. The programme has extended participants for an additional month until end of April to complete fieldwork.

metrics.name: Digitisation of records - National Library of South Africa

implementation_detail.programme_name: Digitisation of records - National Library of South Africa
implementation_detail.detail: The delays in the finalisation of the MoA with the department delayed the project, especially procurement of key equipment and services. The programme will be extending the contracts of appointed participants until June to allow for completion of the work.

The programme will be extended until June to account for significant delays in procurement of equipment and finalisation of the MoA. It has been crucial in enabling the NARSSA to build capacity on digitisation and seeks to digitise one million records.

metrics.name: Job retention in cultural and creative institutions - National Arts Council

dimensions.name: Jobs saved going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.programme_name: Job retention in cultural and creative institutions - National Arts Council
implementation_detail.detail: The call for proposals for the job retention component of the stimulus was undersubscribed. Unallocated funds from job retention were reallocated to augment the funds available to support art and culture practitioners.

metrics.name: Job retention in cultural and creative institutions - National Film and Video Foundation

dimensions.name: Jobs saved going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.programme_name: Job retention in cultural and creative institutions - National Film and Video Foundation
implementation_detail.detail: The call for proposals for the job retention component of the stimulus was undersubscribed. Unallocated funds from job retention were reallocated to augment the funds available to support art and culture practitioners.

metrics.name: Job retention in sport sector - Sport Trust

implementation_detail.programme_name: Job retention in sport sector - Sport Trust
implementation_detail.detail: The programme was oversubscribed and 65 organisations are received support to retain jobs in the sector. The largest component is support to the golf sector to retain and create jobs for caddies. The Sports Trust has requested an extension in order to ensure that all the beneficiaries receive the funds approved.

metrics.name: Support to art and culture practitioners - National Arts Council

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.programme_name: Support to art and culture practitioners - National Arts Council
implementation_detail.detail: The National Arts Council's (NAC) allocated awards that exceeded the total available funds for the programme. In an attempt to remedy this, awards already made were withdrawn and grant amounts revised downwards. The re-allocated funds are still being disbursed and will continue to be disbursed until the last beneficiary receives their funding. The NAC has instituted an investigation into the PESP management process, and that process is underway and will cover the entire scope of the project.

metrics.name: Support to art and culture practitioners - National Film and Video Foundation

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.programme_name: Support to art and culture practitioners - National Film and Video Foundation
implementation_detail.detail: The NFVF call for proposals was oversubscribed with a total of 891 applications received with an excess of 48 000 job proposals. Four streams were adjudicated by Panel of experienced industry specialists, and each stream Chaired by members of the NFVF Council. Panels submitted their recommendations to the NFVF council which made the final approval creating in excess of 8000 jobs.

departments.name: Social Development
departments.lead: Income support to practitioners and to the implementation of Covid compliance measures
departments.paragraph: Livelihoods from the provision of Early Childhood Development services were severely disrupted by the pandemic, with providers facing challenges with re-opening. There are costs associated with doing so safely, plus many sites have faced a loss of income, with some parents unable to afford to pay fees as a result of losing their jobs. To support the sector back on its feet, the ECD Employment Stimulus Relief Fund (ECD –ESRF) is intended to benefit 108 833 workers. This comprises support to 83 333 ECD workers as well as top up payments to 25 500 existing ECD workers, to support Covid-19 compliance at ECD sites. Over 140 civil society organisations have assisted ECD centres to apply for this support.

implementation_detail.detail: The programme faced significant delays and challenges in the planning phase and will not be implemented.

dimensions.name: Jobs saved going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.detail: Appointments and re-appointments have been finalised in several participating programmes and social workers have provided essential social services during the pandemic. The programme concludes at the end of March and some provinces have managed to absorb social workers into permanent positions.

The ECD Employment Stimulus Relief Fund (ECD –ESRF) has been verifying and approving applicants since the end of February. Provincial departments were required to pause payments to beneficiaries at the end March as relief funds were only available for the 2020/21 financial year. Due to delays in the approval of applications and transfer of funds to beneficiaries, only 10% had received payments by the end of March. All provinces have submitted applications to National Treasury to rollover the funds and payments to beneficiaries will resume once applications are approved and provinces have received provisional allocation letters.

departments.name: Science and Innovation
departments.lead: Supporting new graduates entering a hostile labour market
departments.paragraph: Given a constrained labour market, fewer opportunities have been available to graduates leaving institutions of higher learning over this period. The Department of Science and Innovation is delivering four programmes which will together employ 1,900 unemployed graduates. The HSRC is employing graduates as Health Promotion Agents at community level. The Enviro-Champs programme of the Duzi-Umngeni Conservation Trust is supporting water quality testing on the Umngeni River. The Water Research Council is placing graduates with host institutions to conduct water related projects and research while the CSIR has received support to expand its experiential learning programme.

implementation_detail.detail: Following delays, the programme has appointed 42 candidates to begin 1 April. The programme participants will be responsible for building social compacts to initiate behaviour change interventions at community level during the early stages of the Covid-19 pandemic. A dedicated project website has also been developed.

The programme has exceeded the planned numbers due to the addition of a food garden project that required additional labour. Overall, 20 project sites were implemented with teams working across the catchment area on different environmental work in different parts of the river. A team of young graduates is focussing on making sense of the river health data, and gathering stories from communities to compile into a State of the Rivers report, in partnership with Umgeni Water.

Placement of graduates was affected by university system closures which meant students could not register and provide proof as part of the application process however,  the remaining students is currently being placed and the programme is optimistic that the placement target of 189 students will be met.

The programme experienced several challenges with securing hosts for the graduates which led to delays in the two-phased recruitment process. To date, the WRC has finalised appointments for phase 1 of the recruitment and these graduates are placed with various hosts. Phase 2 graduates have been inducted and will also commence their workplace experience soon.

departments.name: Trade, Industry and Competition
departments.lead: Piloting new models for re-shoring and expanding global business services
departments.paragraph: The Global Business Services sector has built from a low base to achieve an average year-on-year export revenue growth of at least 20%. This is as a result of an effective partnership between the dtic and the private sector.  The sector includes call centres and other digital technology services. It is one of few sectors that has been able to grow in the context of Covid-19. The Presidential Employment Stimulus recognised the opportunity to further boost growth in this sector, supporting additional incentives for a target of 8,000 jobs.

implementation_detail.detail: The department has exceeded its target for job creation, facilitated by commitment of additional funds internally to the programme. Most the employed participants are youth and they are engaged in non-complex jobs and complex jobs with the global business services sector.

departments.name: Health
departments.lead: Primary Health Care is at the frontline of the battle against Covid-19
departments.paragraph: As the world responds to the COVID-19 pandemic, the critical role that  health workers play to enhance the resilience of the national health care system has been foregrounded. Community health workers have been on the frontline of active case-finding through screening and contact tracing. In some instances, these workers have been called upon to deliver these services without adequate support and supervision.  Similarly, nursing staff without public facilities have provided much needed care services in the most vulnerable communities. The stimulus support to the sector seeks to augment this capacity and address gaps through the recruitment of additional community health workers and outreach team leaders for supervision. Moreover, additional enrolled and auxiliary nurses are targeted to increase capacity in public health facilities.

implementation_detail.detail: The department faced severe constraints related to rollout in the timeframes and the programme will not be implemented.
The department faced severe constraints related to rollout in the timeframes and the programme will not be implemented.

The programme concludes at the end of March and has exceeded its target for job creation for nurses. The appointed nurses have provided a range of primary health care services in public facilities. Several provinces intend to continue fund further recruitments to support the roll-out of the COVID-19 vaccination programme.

The department concludes this programme at the end of March with an exceeded target for appointed auxiliary nurses. These nurses have supporting various services in public health facilities as part of the response to COVID-19.

departments.name: Transport
departments.lead: Improving access to services and opportunities for people in rural areas
departments.paragraph: Rural roads play a vital role in connecting rural communities to services such as health and education, as well as providing access to markets and economic opportunities. However, rural roads infrastructure remains poor in many areas of South Africa. Provinces are receiving support to scale up rural roads maintenance.

implementation_detail.detail: Despite numerous challenges faced by provincial departments in the planning phase and implementation, projects are in implementation and appointed participants are contributing to the maintenance of rural roads. To date, 4334 km of roads have maintained.
